name: Professor Stephen D. Bentley
description: I’m interested in genomics applications for efforts to reduce the burden of bacterial pathogens causing pneumonia, meningitis and neonatal sepsis in infants in low-income settings.

name: Sophie Belman
description: I study global spatiotemporal dynamics of *Streptococcus pneumoniae* to understand the impact migration has on disease prevalence and prevention.

name: Raymond Hsueh-Chien Cheng
description: I’m interested in studying various modes of evolution in pathogenic bacteria and how they shape different population structure.

name: Dr. Victoria Dyster
description: I work on pathogen detection and emergence in the microbiome, and high quality bioinformatic pipelines and research software for genomic surveillance.

name: Dr. Ana Ferreira
description: I characterise *S. pneumoniae* genome collections at the country/GPSC level to infer biologic insights, enrich the project database with genomes from public databases and support external project partners.

name: Luis González
description: I study the composition, diversity, and functionality of the respiratory microbiome at different sampling sites to understand its assembly dynamics and impact on health and disease.

name: Dr. Harry Hung
description: I work on both the analysis and visualisation of the Global Pneumococcal Sequencing Project.

name: Dr. Dorota Jamrozy
description: I coordinate the JUNO project and study genomics and evolution of Group B *Streptococcus*.

name: Dr. Nida Javaid
description: I am interested in investigating potential vaccine targets for *Streptococcus agalactiae* using genomic and pan-genomic approaches.

name: Dr. Uzma Basit Khan
description: I study antibiotic resistance mechanisms, recombination, mobile genetic elements and transmission in *Streptococcus agalactiae* to comprehend bacterial adaptation and evolution.

name: Dr. Narender Kumar
description: I am responsible for the planning and facilitation of the WGS capacity and infrastructure setup for the GPS project.

name: Dr. Oumie Kuyateh
description: I am interested in understanding how the respiratory microbiome develops in early life and how it is affected by environmental factors such as carbon monoxide exposure, incidences of disease, and antibiotic exposure.

name: Dr. Stephanie Wai-U Lo
description: I oversee the Global Pneumococcal Sequencing Project by setting overall scientific strategy, communicating with collaborators, and delivering outputs through publications.

name: Oliver Lorenz
description: I develop bioinformatics pipelines and research software for the Global Pneumococcal Sequencing Project.

name: Dr. Kate Mellor
description: I am involved with analysis of GPS project data and will also be supporting capacity building and training activities.

name: Dr. Jolynne Mokaya
description: I lead the delivery of genomics training through our GPS and JUNO projects. I am also interested in understanding the genomic epidemiology of bacterial infections prevalent in low- and middle-income countries. Specifically, analysing and predicting patterns of antimicrobial resistance and disease transmission.

name: Eunice Waithira Njuguna
role: PhD Student (London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine)
description: I am interested in understanding the pneumococcal genomic epidemiology in Kenya, focusing on serotype replacement, and applying mathematical models to predict the effectiveness of pneumococcal conjugate vaccines in sub-Saharan Africa.
